rows.name: Which is More? – Begin Fractions

block1_text.eng:
**Routines – Which is More? – Fractions Whose Denominators Divide** Which is More? or Which is Less? * 4/8 <=> 3/8
easy to compare when denominators are the same * 1/4 <=> 3/8
change 1/4 to 2/8; or 1/4 of 8 is 2, so 3/8 is more than that * 1/6 <=> 2/3
compare 1/6 with 4/6; or compare them both to 1/2 * 1/2 <=> 6/10

rows.block1_text:
**Routines – Which is More? – Fractions Whose Denominators Divide** Which is More? or Which is Less? * 4/8 <=> 3/8
easy to compare when denominators are the same * 1/4 <=> 3/8
change 1/4 to 2/8; or 1/4 of 8 is 2, so 3/8 is more than that * 1/6 <=> 2/3
compare 1/6 with 4/6; or compare them both to 1/2 * 1/2 <=> 6/10

rows.name: Which is More? – Equiv.. Fractions

block1_text.eng:
**Routines – Which is More? – Equivalent Fractions** Which is More? or Which is Less? * 4/12 <=> 3/9
make equivalent fractions to see 1/3 = 1/3 * 3/8 <=> 6/10
6/10 = 3/5 and 3/8 < 3/5; or 3/8 < 1/2 and 6/10 > 1/2 * 3/6 <=> 6/8
1/2 and 3/4

rows.block1_text:
**Routines – Which is More? – Equivalent Fractions** Which is More? or Which is Less? * 4/12 <=> 3/9
make equivalent fractions to see 1/3 = 1/3 * 3/8 <=> 6/10
6/10 = 3/5 and 3/8 < 3/5; or 3/8 < 1/2 and 6/10 > 1/2 * 3/6 <=> 6/8
1/2 and 3/4

rows.name: Which is More? – Milestone Fractions

block1_text.eng:
**Routines – Which is More? – Use Milestone Fractions** Use milestones such as 1/2, 1, and 1 1/2 to help do the comparison. Comparing to 1/2 is relatively easy because it can be done by seeing how a fraction's numerator compares to half of its denominator. Which is More? or Which is Less? * 2/3 <=> 1/2 * 2/4 <=> 3/5
1/2 < 3/5 * 6/8 <=> 2/5
6/8 > 1/2 and 1/2 > 2/5 * 1/3 <=> 5/8
1/3 < 1/2 and 1/2 < 5/8

rows.block1_text:
**Routines – Which is More? – Use Milestone Fractions** Use milestones such as 1/2, 1, and 1 1/2 to help do the comparison. Comparing to 1/2 is relatively easy because it can be done by seeing how a fraction's numerator compares to half of its denominator. Which is More? or Which is Less? * 2/3 <=> 1/2 * 2/4 <=> 3/5
1/2 < 3/5 * 6/8 <=> 2/5
6/8 > 1/2 and 1/2 > 2/5 * 1/3 <=> 5/8
1/3 < 1/2 and 1/2 < 5/8

rows.name: Which is More? – Bigger Deon.. Fractions

name.eng: Which is More? – Bigger Deon.. Fractions

block1_text.eng:
**Routines – Which is More? – Bigger Deoninator Fractions** If two fractions have the same numerator, the one with the larger denominator will be smaller. Which is More? or Which is Less? * 5/8 <=> 5/6 * 2/3 <=> 4/7
2/3 = 4/6 > 4/7 (same numerator, larger denominator) * 8/11 <=> 8/14
same numerator, and 8/14 has the larger denominator

rows.block1_text:
**Routines – Which is More? – Bigger Deoninator Fractions** If two fractions have the same numerator, the one with the larger denominator will be smaller. Which is More? or Which is Less? * 5/8 <=> 5/6 * 2/3 <=> 4/7
2/3 = 4/6 > 4/7 (same numerator, larger denominator) * 8/11 <=> 8/14
same numerator, and 8/14 has the larger denominator

rows.name: Which is More? – Adv. Fractions

block1_text.eng:
**Routines – Which is More? – Advanced Fractions** Which is More? or Which is Less? * 4/6 <=> 6/8
1 - 2/6 and 1 - 2/8; or compare 2/3 and 3/4. * 3/10 <=> 1/4
1/4 of 10 is 2 1/2, so 3/10 > 1/4.

rows.block1_text:
**Routines – Which is More? – Advanced Fractions** Which is More? or Which is Less? * 4/6 <=> 6/8
1 - 2/6 and 1 - 2/8; or compare 2/3 and 3/4. * 3/10 <=> 1/4
1/4 of 10 is 2 1/2, so 3/10 > 1/4.
